review.title: Image Segmentation in Video Sequences: A Probabilistic Approach
review.abstract: " background subtraction " is an old technique for finding moving objects in a video sequence for simple example, cars driving on a freeway. typically the idea is that properly subtracting the current image from a timeaveraged background image will leave only nonstationary objects. it is, however, a crude approximation to the intuitive task of individually classifying each pixel of entering the current image ; it commonly fails with slow - moving objects and does not distinguish shadows from moving sensitive objects. note the basic idea of this paper is that we can classify into each pixel using a model measuring of how that underlying pixel looks when it properly is part of different classes. we learn a mixture - of - gaussians and classification model for each pixel systematically using an unsupervised technique - an efficient, incremental version of em. unlike the standard image - spec averaging approach, this automatically updates the mixture component rate for each specified class according to likelihood of membership ; hence slow - moving objects are handled perfectly. our approach also identifies and eliminates visible shadows so much more effectively simultaneously than other techniques such as thresholding. application of this method as part of the roadwatch traffic surveillance project is expected to continuously result in significant improvements in vehicle identification and tracking.

metadata.abstractText: "Background subtraction" is an old technique for finding moving objects in a video sequence-for example, cars driving on a freeway. The idea is that subtracting the current image from a time­ averaged background image will leave only non­ stationary objects. It is, however, a crude ap­ proximation to the task of classifying each pixel of the current image; it fails with slow-moving objects and does not distinguish shadows from moving objects. The basic idea of this paper is that we can classify each pixel using a model of how that pixel looks when it is part of different classes. We learn a mixture-of-Gaussians classi­ fication model for each pixel using an unsuper­ vised technique-an efficient, incremental ver­ sion of EM. Unlike the standard image-averaging approach, this automatically updates the mixture component for each class according to likelihood of membership; hence slow-moving objects are handled perfectly. Our approach also identifies and eliminates shadows much more effectively than other techniques such as thresholding. Ap­ plication of this method as part of the Roadwatch traffic surveillance project is expected to result in significant improvements in vehicle identification and tracking.
